clinical_study.brief_title: A Study Of Efficacy And Safety Of Fesoterodine In Vulnerable Elderly Subjects With Overactive Bladder
clinical_study.official_title: A 12-Week, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled, Parallel-Group, Multicenter Trial To Evaluate The Efficacy And Safety Of Fesoterodine Flexible Dose Regimen In Vulnerable Elderly Patients With Overactive Bladder.

brief_summary.textblock: This study is designed to assess the efficacy and safety of a flexible dose regimen of fesoterodine on urgency urinary incontinence (UUI) episodes in vulnerable elderly subjects with overactive bladder (OAB).

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Mean Number of Urgency Urinary Incontinence (UUI) Episodes Per 24 Hours
primary_outcome.description: UUI episodes were defined as those with the Urinary Sensation Scale (USS) rating of 5 in the diary. USS total range 1 to 5: 1. No feeling of urgency, 2. Mild feeling of urgency, 3. Moderate feeling of urgency, 4. Severe feeling of urgency, 5. Unable to hold; leak urine.

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Mean Number of Urgency Urinary Incontinence (UUI) Episodes Per 24 Hours at Week 12
primary_outcome.description: UUI episodes were defined as those with the USS rating of 5 in the diary. USS total range 1 to 5: 1. No feeling of urgency, 2. Mild feeling of urgency, 3. Moderate feeling of urgency, 4. Severe feeling of urgency, 5. Unable to hold; leak urine.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Mean Number of Urgency Urinary Incontinence (UUI) Episodes Per 24 Hours at Week 4
secondary_outcome.description: UUI episodes were defined as those with the USS rating of 5 in the diary. USS total range 1 to 5: 1. No feeling of urgency, 2. Mild feeling of urgency, 3. Moderate feeling of urgency, 4. Severe feeling of urgency, 5. Unable to hold; leak urine.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change From Baseline in Urgency Urinary Incontinence (UUI) Episodes Per 24 Hours at Week 4 and 12
secondary_outcome.description: Percent change of UUI episodes per 24 hours was calculated as change in 24-hour mean at that visit divided by the baseline 24-hour mean multiplied by 100 (i.e., 100*(Week 4 or 12 - baseline)/baseline).

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Number of Micturitions Per 24 Hours
secondary_outcome.description: Micturitions include episodes of voluntary micturition and episodes of UUI. UUI episodes were defined as those micturitions with USS rating of 5 in the diary in participants with UUI at baseline. USS rating 5: Unable to hold; leak urine.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Mean Number of Micturitions Per 24 Hours at Week 4 and 12
secondary_outcome.description: Micturitions include episodes of voluntary micturition and episodes of UUI. UUI episodes were defined as those micturitions with USS rating of 5 in the diary in participants with UUI at baseline. USS rating 5: Unable to hold; leak urine.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change From Baseline in Micturitions Per 24 Hours at Week 4 and 12
secondary_outcome.description: Percent change of micturitions per 24 hours was calculated as change in 24-hour mean at that visit divided by the baseline 24-hour mean multiplied by 100 (i.e., 100*(Week 4 or 12 - baseline)/baseline).

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Number of Micturition-related Urgency Episodes Per 24 Hours
secondary_outcome.description: The mean number of micturition-related urgency episodes per 24 hours was calculated as the total number of micturitions with USS rating of greater than or equal to (>=) 3 divided by the total number of days that diary data was collected at that visit. USS total range 1 to 5: 1. No feeling of urgency, 2. Mild feeling of urgency, 3. Moderate feeling of urgency, 4. Severe feeling of urgency, 5. Unable to hold; leak urine.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Mean Number of Micturition-related Urgency Episodes Per 24 Hours at Week 4 and 12
secondary_outcome.description: The mean number of micturition-related urgency episodes per 24 hours was calculated as the total number of micturitions with USS rating of greater than or equal to (>=) 3 divided by the total number of days that diary data was collected at that visit. USS total range 1 to 5: 1. No feeling of urgency, 2. Mild feeling of urgency, 3. Moderate feeling of urgency, 4. Severe feeling of urgency, 5. Unable to hold; leak urine.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change From Baseline in Micturition-related Urgency Episodes Per 24 Hours at Week 4 and 12
secondary_outcome.description: Percent change of micturition-related urgency episodes per 24 hours was calculated as change in 24-hour mean at that visit divided by the baseline 24-hour mean multiplied by 100 (i.e., 100*(Week 4 or 12 - baseline)/baseline).

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Number of Nocturnal Micturition-related Urgency Episodes Per 24 Hours
secondary_outcome.description: Nocturnal micturition-related urgency episodes had USS rating of 3 or more that occurred between time participant went to bed and time he or she arose to start next day. Number of nocturnal micturition-related urgency episodes per 24 hours was calculated as sum of all nocturnal micturition-related urgency episodes divided by total number of diary days collected at that visit.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Mean Number of Nocturnal Micturition-related Urgency Episodes Per 24 Hours at Week 4 and 12
secondary_outcome.description: Nocturnal micturition-related urgency episodes had USS rating of 3 or more that occurred between time participant went to bed and time he or she arose to start next day. Number of nocturnal micturition-related urgency episodes per 24 hours was calculated as sum of all nocturnal micturition-related urgency episodes divided by total number of diary days collected at that visit.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change From Baseline in Nocturnal Micturition-related Urgency Episodes Per 24 Hours at Week 4 and 12
secondary_outcome.description: Percent change of nocturnal micturition-related urgency episodes per 24 hours was calculated as change in 24-hour mean at that visit divided by the baseline 24-hour mean multiplied by 100 (i.e., 100*(Week 4 or 12 - baseline)/baseline).

secondary_outcome.measure: Frequency-Urgency Sum Rating Per 24 Hours
secondary_outcome.description: Frequency-urgency sum is total USS ratings recorded for all micturitions in 24-hour day. Number of USS ratings per 24 hours is sum of all USS ratings divided by the total diary days collected at that visit. USS scale: 1=No feeling of urgency to 5=Unable to hold: leak urine.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Frequency-Urgency Sum Rating Per 24 Hours at Week 4 and 12
secondary_outcome.description: Frequency-urgency sum is total USS ratings recorded for all micturitions in 24-hour day. Number of USS ratings per 24 hours is sum of all USS ratings divided by the total diary days collected at that visit. USS scale: 1=No feeling of urgency to 5=Unable to hold: leak urine. Numerical decrease indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Mean Number of Protective Undergarments Changed Due to Urinary Leakage Per 24 Hours at Week 4 and 12
secondary_outcome.description: Protective Undergarments included pads, protective padding, protective underwear (pull up), and briefs (diaper). The mean number of undergarments changed per 24 hours was calculated as the total number of undergarments changed divided by the total number of diary days collected at that visit. Change from baseline values were reported at week 4 for subsets of population with baseline values less than or equal to (=<) 3.5 and more than (>) 3.5 undergarments/day and at Week 12 for subsets of population with baseline values =< 2.5 and > 2.5 undergarments/day.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With Change From Screening in Patient Perception of Bladder Condition (PPBC) at Week 4 and 12
secondary_outcome.description: PPBC: a self-administered, single-item, questionnaire that asks participants to describe their perception of their bladder-related problems. The PPBC assessment is rated on a 6-point scale: 1=no problems at all, 2=some very minor problems, 3=some minor problems, 4=moderate problems, 5=severe problems, 6=many severe problems. Deterioration=score difference is greater than 0; no change=score difference is 0; minor improvement=score difference is -1; major difference=score difference is less than or equal to -2.

secondary_outcome.measure: Overactive Bladder Questionnaire (OAB-q) Symptom Bother Score
secondary_outcome.description: OAB-q: a self-administered, 33-item, questionnaire that assesses how much the participant has been bothered by selected bladder symptoms. Each item rated by participant on Likert scale 1 (least symptom bother) to 6 (most symptom bother). Symptom bother score derived as sum of scores for questions 1-8; lowest possible raw score: 8; highest possible score: 48. Data analyzed based on transformation of the score to a 0 to 100 scale [(Actual total raw score - lowest possible value of raw score)/range]*100. Higher scores values indicative of greater symptom bother.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Overactive Bladder Questionnaire (OAB-q) Symptom Bother Score at Week 4 and 12
secondary_outcome.description: OAB-q: a self-administered, 33-item, questionnaire that assesses how much the participant has been bothered by selected bladder symptoms. Each item rated by participant on Likert scale 1 (least symptom bother) to 6 (most symptom bother). Symptom bother score derived as sum of scores for questions 1-8; lowest possible raw score: 8; highest possible score: 48. Data analyzed based on transformation of the score to a 0 to 100 scale [(Actual total raw score - lowest possible value of raw score)/range]*100. Higher scores values indicative of greater symptom bother.

secondary_outcome.measure: Health Related Quality of Life (HRQL) Domain and Total Score of Overactive Bladder Questionnaire (OAB-q)
secondary_outcome.description: OAB-q: self-administered, 33-item, questionnaire, assesses how much participant has been bothered by selected bladder symptoms. Each item rated on Likert scale 1 (least symptom bother) to 6 (most symptom bother). Questions 9 to 33 constitute HRQL, includes domains: concern, coping, sleep, and social function. HRQL domain and total raw score derived as sum of scores. Transformed score range 0 to 100 (Total HRQL or domain) = [(Highest possible raw score-Actual total raw score)/Raw score range]*100. Higher transformed scores indicative of better HRQL.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Health Related Quality of Life (HRQL) Domain and Total Score of Overactive Bladder Questionnaire (OAB-q) at Week 4 and 12
secondary_outcome.description: OAB-q: self-administered, 33-item, questionnaire, assesses how much participant has been bothered by selected bladder symptoms. Each item rated on Likert scale 1 (least symptom bother) to 6 (most symptom bother). Questions 9 to 33 constitute HRQL, includes domains: concern, coping, sleep, and social function. HRQL domain and total raw score derived as sum of scores. Transformed score range 0 to 100 (Total HRQL or domain) = [(Highest possible raw score-Actual total raw score)/Raw score range]*100. Higher transformed scores indicative of better HRQL.

secondary_outcome.measure: Overactive Bladder Satisfaction Questionnaire (OAB-S) Total Score on Satisfaction With OAB Control
secondary_outcome.description: OAB-S: a validated self-administered instrument that evaluates OAB medication expectations, daily life with AB, and satisfaction with OAB medication and includes 3 stand-alone items that assess overall expectation, satisfaction, and willingness to continue treatment. Satisfaction coded on scale of 1 to 5: (1=very satisfied to 5=very dissatisfied). Coding reversed algorithmically and results transformed: total score range 0 to100. Higher final response value associated with better satisfaction.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With Overactive Bladder Satisfaction Questionnaire (OAB-S) Global Medication Satisfaction Question Response
secondary_outcome.description: Participant's response to question, "overall, how satisfied are you with your OAB medication?" was obtained on a 5 point scale, 1- very satisfied, 2- somewhat satisfied, 3- neither dissatisfied nor satisfied, 4- somewhat dissatisfied and 5- very dissatisfied. Response values 1 and 2 were combined into "satisfied", and 4 and 5 were combined into "dissatisfied".

secondary_outcome.measure: Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE)
secondary_outcome.description: MMSE measured general cognitive functioning: orientation, memory, attention, calculation, language, visuospatial functions. Total score derived from sub-scores; total ranges from 0 to 30, higher score indicates better cognitive state.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Screening in Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) Score at Week 12
secondary_outcome.description: MMSE measured general cognitive functioning: orientation, memory, attention, calculation, language, visuospatial functions. Total score derived from sub-scores; total ranges from 0 to 30, higher score indicates better cognitive state. Change: mean score at Week X minus mean score at baseline

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Post Void Residual (PVR) Volume at Week 4 and 12
secondary_outcome.description: PVR volume is defined as volume of urine remaining in the bladder immediately after urination.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- male or female subjects 65 years of age or older
- OAB symptoms for at least 3 months
- score 3 or greater on Vulnerable Elderly Survey (VES-13)
- adequate mobility for independent toileting
- mean number of at least 2 UUI episodes per 24 hours
- mean urinary frequency of 8 or more micturitions per 24 hours
- able to independently complete the bladder diaries
Exclusion Criteria:
- PVR urinary volume greater than 200 ml
- MMSE score less than 20
- greater than 15 UUI episodes per 24 hours
- creatinine clearance less than 30 ml/min
- an average resting heart rate of greater than or equal to 90 beats per minute

outcome.description: UUI episodes were defined as those with the Urinary Sensation Scale (USS) rating of 5 in the diary. USS total range 1 to 5: 1. No feeling of urgency, 2. Mild feeling of urgency, 3. Moderate feeling of urgency, 4. Severe feeling of urgency, 5. Unable to hold; leak urine.
outcome.population: Full analysis set (FAS) population included all participants who received at least 1 dose of study drug and had at least 1 baseline or post-baseline efficacy assessment. outcome.description: Nocturnal micturition-related urgency episodes had USS rating of 3 or more that occurred between time participant went to bed and time he or she arose to start next day. outcome.description: Frequency-urgency sum is total USS ratings recorded for all micturitions in 24-hour day. Number of USS ratings per 24 hours is sum of all USS ratings divided by the total diary days collected at that visit. USS scale: 1=No feeling of urgency to 5=Unable to hold: leak urine.
outcome.population: FAS population. Here, 'N' (number of participants analyzed) signifies those participants who had baseline frequency urgency sum rating greater than 0 per 24 hours and non-missing change from baseline value at Week 12.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Mean Number of Protective Undergarments Changed Due to Urinary Leakage Per 24 Hours at Week 4 and 12
outcome.description: Protective Undergarments included pads, protective padding, protective underwear (pull up), and briefs (diaper). The mean number of undergarments changed per 24 hours was calculated as the total number of undergarments changed divided by the total number of diary days collected at that visit. Change from baseline values were reported at week 4 for subsets of population with baseline values less than or equal to (=<) 3.5 and more than (>) 3.5 undergarments/day and at Week 12 for subsets of population with baseline values =< 2.5 and > 2.5 undergarments/day.
outcome.population: FAS population. LOCF method was used to impute only Week 12 missing data but not Week 4 missing data. Here, 'n' is signifying those participants of the population subsets who were evaluated for this measure at the time point for each group respectively.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Placebo matched to fesoterodine 4 milligram (mg) oral tablet once daily for 4 weeks followed by placebo matched to fesoterodine 8 mg once daily as part of optional dose escalation at investigator's discretion for remaining 8 weeks.

group.title: Fesoterodine
group.description: Fesoterodine 4 mg oral tablet once daily for 4 weeks followed by an optional dose-escalation to 8 mg once daily at investigator’s discretion for remaining 8 weeks.

measure.title: Change From Baseline in Mean Number of Protective Undergarments Changed Due to Urinary Leakage Per 24 Hours at Week 4 and 12
measure.description: Protective Undergarments included pads, protective padding, protective underwear (pull up), and briefs (diaper). The mean number of undergarments changed per 24 hours was calculated as the total number of undergarments changed divided by the total number of diary days collected at that visit. Change from baseline values were reported at week 4 for subsets of population with baseline values less than or equal to (=<) 3.5 and more than (>) 3.5 undergarments/day and at Week 12 for subsets of population with baseline values =< 2.5 and > 2.5 undergarments/day.
measure.population: FAS population. LOCF method was used to impute only Week 12 missing data but not Week 4 missing data. Here, 'n' is signifying those participants of the population subsets who were evaluated for this measure at the time point for each group respectively.

analysis.groups_desc: Change at Week 4: =<3.5 undergarments- Protective undergarment usage was analyzed to compare treatments on separate subsets, based on baseline protective undergarment use (=<3.5/day and >3.5/day), using a 2 sample t-test. This method was applied because there was a statistically significant qualitative baseline by treatment interaction.
analysis.p_value_desc: Statistical testing, two-sided, was done at 5% alpha level.

analysis.groups_desc: Change at Week 4: >3.5 undergarments- Protective undergarment usage was analyzed to compare treatments on separate subsets, based on baseline protective undergarment use (=<3.5/day and >3.5/day), using a 2 sample t-test. This method was applied because there was a statistically significant qualitative baseline by treatment interaction.
analysis.p_value_desc: Statistical testing, two-sided, was done at 5% alpha level.

analysis.groups_desc: Change at Week 12: =<2.5 undergarments- Protective undergarment usage was analyzed to compare treatments on separate subsets, based on baseline protective undergarment use (=<2.5/day and >2.5/day), using a 2 sample t-test. This method was applied because there was a statistically significant qualitative baseline by treatment interaction.
analysis.p_value_desc: Statistical testing, two-sided, was done at 5% alpha level.

analysis.groups_desc: Change at Week 12: >2.5 undergarments- Protective undergarment usage was analyzed to compare treatments on separate subsets, based on baseline protective undergarment use (=<2.5/day and >2.5/day), using a 2 sample t-test. This method was applied because there was a statistically significant qualitative baseline by treatment interaction.
analysis.p_value_desc: Statistical testing, two-sided, was done at 5% alpha level.

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants With Change From Screening in Patient Perception of Bladder Condition (PPBC) at Week 4 and 12
outcome.description: PPBC: a self-administered, single-item, questionnaire that asks participants to describe their perception of their bladder-related problems. The PPBC assessment is rated on a 6-point scale: 1=no problems at all, 2=some very minor problems, 3=some minor problems, 4=moderate problems, 5=severe problems, 6=many severe problems. Deterioration=score difference is greater than 0; no change=score difference is 0; minor improvement=score difference is -1; major difference=score difference is less than or equal to -2.
outcome.population: FAS population. LOCF method was used to impute only Week 12 missing data but not Week 4 missing data. Here, 'N' (number of participants analyzed) signifies those participants who had non-missing change from baseline value at Week 12.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Placebo matched to fesoterodine 4 milligram (mg) oral tablet once daily for 4 weeks followed by placebo matched to fesoterodine 8 mg once daily as part of optional dose escalation at investigator's discretion for remaining 8 weeks.

group.title: Fesoterodine
group.description: Fesoterodine 4 mg oral tablet once daily for 4 weeks followed by an optional dose-escalation to 8 mg once daily at investigator’s discretion for remaining 8 weeks.

measure.title: Percentage of Participants With Change From Screening in Patient Perception of Bladder Condition (PPBC) at Week 4 and 12
measure.description: PPBC: a self-administered, single-item, questionnaire that asks participants to describe their perception of their bladder-related problems. measure.population: FAS population. LOCF method was used to impute only Week 12 missing data but not Week 4 missing data. Here, 'N' (number of participants analyzed) signifies those participants who had non-missing change from baseline value at Week 12.

analysis.groups_desc: Change at Week 4- deterioration, no change, minor improvement and major improvement: Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel (CMH) test with modified ridit scoring controlling for center was used to calculate p-value.
analysis.p_value_desc: Statistical testing, two-sided, was done at 5% alpha level.

analysis.groups_desc: Change at Week 12- deterioration, no change, minor improvement and major improvement: CMH test with modified ridit scoring controlling for center was used to calculate p-value.
analysis.p_value_desc: Statistical testing, two-sided, was done at 5% alpha level.

outcome.title: Overactive Bladder Questionnaire (OAB-q) Symptom Bother Score
outcome.description: OAB-q: a self-administered, 33-item, questionnaire that assesses how much the participant has been bothered by selected bladder symptoms. Each item rated by participant on Likert scale 1 (least symptom bother) to 6 (most symptom bother). Symptom bother score derived as sum of scores for questions 1-8; lowest possible raw score: 8; highest possible score: 48. Data analyzed based on transformation of the score to a 0 to 100 scale [(Actual total raw score – lowest possible value of raw score)/range]*100. Higher scores values indicative of greater symptom bother.
outcome.population: FAS population included all participants who received at least 1 dose of study drug and had at least 1 baseline or post-baseline efficacy assessment. Here, 'N' (number of participants analyzed) signifies those participants who had non-missing change from baseline value at both Weeks 4 and 12.

outcome.title: Health Related Quality of Life (HRQL) Domain and Total Score of Overactive Bladder Questionnaire (OAB-q)
outcome.description: OAB-q: self-administered, 33-item, questionnaire, assesses how much participant has been bothered by selected bladder symptoms. Each item rated on Likert scale 1 (least symptom bother) to 6 (most symptom bother). Questions 9 to 33 constitute HRQL, includes domains: concern, coping, sleep, and social function. HRQL domain and total raw score derived as sum of scores. Transformed score range 0 to 100 (Total HRQL or domain) = [(Highest possible raw score-Actual total raw score)/Raw score range]*100. Higher transformed scores indicative of better HRQL.
outcome.population: FAS population included all participants who received at least 1 dose of study drug and had at least 1 baseline or post-baseline efficacy assessment. Here, 'N' (number of participants analyzed) signifies those participants who had non-missing change from baseline value at both Week 4 and 12.

measure.title: Change From Baseline in Health Related Quality of Life (HRQL) Domain and Total Score of Overactive Bladder Questionnaire (OAB-q) at Week 4 and 12
measure.description: OAB-q: self-administered, 33-item, questionnaire, assesses how much participant has been bothered by selected bladder symptoms. Each item rated on Likert scale 1 (least symptom bother) to 6 (most symptom bother). Questions 9 to 33 constitute HRQL, includes domains: concern, coping, sleep, and social function. HRQL domain and total raw score derived as sum of scores. Transformed score range 0 to 100 (Total HRQL or domain) = [(Highest possible raw score-Actual total raw score)/Raw score range]*100. Higher transformed scores indicative of better HRQL.
measure.population: FAS population included all participants who received at least 1 dose of study drug and had at least 1 baseline or post-baseline efficacy assessment. LOCF method was used to impute Week 12 missing data. Here, 'N' (number of participants analyzed) signifies those participants who had non-missing change from baseline value at both Week 4 and 12.

outcome.title: Overactive Bladder Satisfaction Questionnaire (OAB-S) Total Score on Satisfaction With OAB Control
outcome.description: OAB-S: a validated self-administered instrument that evaluates OAB medication expectations, daily life with AB, and satisfaction with OAB medication and includes 3 stand-alone items that assess overall expectation, satisfaction, and willingness to continue treatment. Satisfaction coded on scale of 1 to 5: (1=very satisfied to 5=very dissatisfied). Coding reversed algorithmically and results transformed: total score range 0 to100. Higher final response value associated with better satisfaction.
outcome.population: FAS population included all participants who received at least 1 dose of study drug and had at least 1 baseline or post-baseline efficacy assessment. Here, 'N' (number of participants analyzed) signifies those participants who had non-missing value at Week 12.

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants With Overactive Bladder Satisfaction Questionnaire (OAB-S) Global Medication Satisfaction Question Response
outcome.description: Participant's response to question, "overall, how satisfied are you with your OAB medication?" was obtained on a 5 point scale, 1- very satisfied, 2- somewhat satisfied, 3- neither dissatisfied nor satisfied, 4- somewhat dissatisfied and 5- very dissatisfied. Response values 1 and 2 were combined into "satisfied", and 4 and 5 were combined into "dissatisfied".
outcome.population: FAS population included all participants who received at least 1 dose of study drug and had at least 1 baseline or post-baseline efficacy assessment. Here, 'N' (number of participants analyzed) signifies those participants who had non-missing value at Week 12.

outcome.description: MMSE measured general cognitive functioning: orientation, memory, attention, calculation, language, visuospatial functions. Total score derived from sub-scores; total ranges from 0 to 30, higher score indicates better cognitive state.

Here, 'N' (number of participants analyzed) signifies those participants who had non-missing change from baseline value at Week 12.

Total score derived from sub-scores; total ranges from 0 to 30, higher score indicates better cognitive state. Change: mean score at Week X minus mean score at baseline
outcome.population: FAS population included all participants who received at least 1 dose of study drug and had at least 1 baseline or post-baseline efficacy assessment. outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Post Void Residual (PVR) Volume at Week 4 and 12
outcome.description: PVR volume is defined as volume of urine remaining in the bladder immediately after urination.
outcome.population: FAS population. LOCF method was used to impute only Week 12 missing data but not Week 4 missing data. Here, 'N' (number of participants analyzed) signifies those participants who had non-missing change from baseline value at Week 12.

group.title: Placebo

measure.title: Change From Baseline in Post Void Residual (PVR) Volume at Week 4 and 12
measure.description: PVR volume is defined as volume of urine remaining in the bladder immediately after urination.
measure.population: FAS population. LOCF method was used to impute only Week 12 missing data but not Week 4 missing data. Here, 'N' (number of participants analyzed) signifies those participants who had non-missing change from baseline value at Week 12.

analysis.groups_desc: Change at Week 4: Van Elteren's test adjusted by baseline PVR quartile was used to calculate p-value. The median difference was based on Hodges-Lehmann estimate.
analysis.p_value_desc: Statistical testing, two-sided, was done at 5% alpha level.

analysis.groups_desc: Change at Week 12: Van Elteren's test adjusted by baseline PVR quartile was used to calculate p-value. The median difference was based on Hodges-Lehmann estimate.
analysis.p_value_desc: Statistical testing, two-sided, was done at 5% alpha level.

reported_events.desc: The same event may appear as both an AE and a SAE. However, what is presented are distinct events. An event may be categorized as serious in one subject and as nonserious in another subject, or one subject may have experienced both a serious and nonserious event during the study.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: Pfizer has the right to review disclosures, requesting a delay of less than 60 days. Investigator will postpone single center publications until after disclosure of pooled data (all sites), less than 12 months from study completion/termination at all participating sites. Investigator may not disclose previously undisclosed confidential information other than study results.
